Sure! Here's a problem for you to solve:

A sample of radioactive material has an initial mass of 200 grams and a half-life of 5 days. Write an equation to model the mass of the sample as a function of time, and use it to find the mass after 15 days.
message_2:
To model the mass of the radioactive material as a function of time, we can use the exponential decay formula:

M(t) = M₀ * (1/2)^(t/T)

where M(t) is the mass of the material at time t, M₀ is the initial mass, t is the time in days, and T is the half-life of the material.

In this problem, M₀ = 200 grams and T = 5 days. So the equation becomes:

M(t) = 200 * (1/2)^(t/5)

Now, we want to find the mass after 15 days. So, we'll plug in t = 15 into the equation:

M(15) = 200 * (1/2)^(15/5)

M(15) = 200 * (1/2)^3

M(15) = 200 * (1/8)

M(15) = 25 grams

So, after 15 days, the mass of the radioactive material will be 25 grams.
